question_text: What to expect from O.A. infarction
45 YO female came with SAH and found to have P-chom aneurysm what's next
Clear scenario of anterior choroidal artery infarction, they brought VF suggestive of it
Stroke all stroke workups mentioned except CTA asked what to do next

Scenario patient feeling unwell, then start seeing animals after which he had decreased LOC intubated, decerebrate posturing CT brain attached showed hyperdense basilar sign otherwise no clear ischemic changes what to do next

options.option_a: (CTA) is correct because after seeing the hyperdense basilar sign, CTA is the appropriate next diagnostic step to determine the exact location and extent of the occlusion. Option B (EEG) is incorrect because EEG evaluates electrical brain activity and is not useful in diagnosing vascular occlusions.

question_text: Rt small thalamic hemorrhage since one day, BP normal, pic attached no hydro or ventricular extension what to do next

options.option_a: (Prophylactic LMWH) is correct and is supported by current guidelines for preventing thromboembolic complications in patients with stable intracerebral hemorrhage. Option B (EVD) is incorrect because external ventricular drainage is reserved for cases with significant hydrocephalus or intraventricular hemorrhage, which is not present in this case.

question_text: Male with progressive myelopathy attached image clearly showing slow void, and long cord signal changes, dx

options.option_a: (DAVF) is correct because the clinical presentation of a progressive myelopathy combined with the specific MRI findings (slow flow voids and long cord signal abnormalities) strongly supports a diagnosis of spinal dural arteriovenous fistula. Other options such as multiple sclerosis, transverse myelitis, or neoplasm lack the combination of flow voids and progressive cord changes seen in DAVF.

question_text: Male with renal impairment, stroke, angiokeratoma pic asking about enzyme supp

options.option_a: , which corresponds to enzyme replacement with alpha

question_text: 14 years old boy with intense lancinating pain in feet. His 16 years old sister has same but milder symptoms. There is positive history of strokes in his maternal grandfather before age of 50. On examination; ↓ pain sensation distally. His lower trunk evident for abnormal skin lesions as attached. What is the best test to reach diagnosis?

A 66-year-old male patient presented with dysarthria and right sided weakness for 10 hours. CT brain done and showed acute ischemic change over the the left internal capsule (No attached image).

Which of the following is the next step in the management?
A 60s-year-old male presented to the ER with 2 days history of unilateral weakness and dysarthria. On examination, BP 170/90, HR 80s. What is the next step in the management?

An elderly male presented to the ER with right sided weakness aphasia, Examination showed BP 220/120, HR 90s, patient was drowsy, aphasic, with right sided weakness NIHSS high (not sure about the number). What is the next step in management?

Female patient with ESRD on regular hemodialysis complaining of recurrent TIAs last for less than 10 minutes inform of left sided weakness and dysarthria then resolved completely. These symptoms occur during the dialysis sessions. CT brain done and showed evidence of old ischemic stroke. Carotid US done and showed left ICA atherosclerotic changes with no visualized stenosis or occlusion.
Which of the following is important to order during evaluation of this patient?
Female patient came with ischemic stroke, history of previous 2 abortions, elevated prothrombin time. What is the most helpful investigation in her case?

A 30-year-old healthy women presented with 10 days history of severe headache, blurred vision and new onset symptomatic seizure. Neurological examination was unremarkable. Vitaly stable.

CT brain done (image attached).

Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?

Patient presented with acute limb weakness and dysarthria. CT brain done and was normal. He was within the window and IV t-PA started. 20 minutes later the primary nurse called the physician as the patient has abnormal swelling around the mouth (imaged attached). Blood pressure was normal.

Which of the following is the most likely associated risk factor for this condition?
